title: Olympic dreams come with intense agony and scrutiny, but I would do it all again | Opinion
description: What does it really take to win an Olympic medal? Sasha Cohen shares her path to silver at the 2006 Turin Games, and the pressure and pain that goes with it.
fullText:
Twenty years ago, I was on the Olympic podium in Turin, Italy. Now, I’m back as a spectator, watching the figure skating events with both nostalgia and relief as I relive the highs and lows of my Olympic experience. I was keenly reminded of my own choice to pursue the Olympic dream at the expense of all else.

It stirred reflections on my skating career and all that has transpired since. Knowing what it took, I would still do it again in a heartbeat. At the same time, it’s hard to imagine my kids following in my footsteps — not only because of what I missed out on, but the weight of the hopes and expectations I carried.

I first fell in love with the feeling of gliding across the ice at age seven. The next 10 years were full of joyful growth, quickly mastering difficult jumps, and early competitive success. Early mornings in cold damp ice rinks were filled with possibility and promise. I couldn’t get enough and hated anything keeping me away from the ice.

But when I was just 12, I was forced to take months off when another skater collided with me, slicing my calf open. Then again at 15 I fractured my lower back, sidelined for another three months. The time away from the ice only strengthened my resolve and commitment to qualify for the 2002 Olympic Games in Salt Lake City. I made the games, but missed the podium and ended up a disappointing 4th place, determined to come back in 2006 and redeem myself.

I moved across the country to work with a coach known internationally for minting Olympic champions, shutting down any outside interests. It paid off and I had my best year yet, winning almost every competition I entered.

But the time between the Olympics is long. Two years in and still a long two years out; stress mounted and joy faded. 2004 was a particularly brutal year; I withdrew from a season of competitions, crippled by mental health struggles and tortured by long, anxiety ridden nights, precipitated by the growing fear that my best days were behind me.

Just two years earlier, I was a fresh upstart with almost no senior international experience. Making the Olympic team as a 17-year-old in my home country felt like there was only possibility ahead.

Four years later, in 2006, I knew most of my career was behind me, and I was weighed down by the tremendous weight of expectation —mine, and my country’s. It was most likely my last shot at Olympic gold, but injuries marred my training leading up to the Games.

That’s the thing about an Olympic career, one can spend a whole lifetime training for a certain moment in time, only to be thwarted by the body’s limits.

I knew that even one mistake would cost me Gold and that two would likely knock me off the podium. In the end, I stumbled but so did my competitors. I took home the silver.

The Olympics are the most glorious and, arguably, agonizing of human endeavors. With the gift of time, I am profoundly aware of the dark side that we glaze over, often oblivious to the costs. The world isharsh in judging our hero athletes — the media’s adulation over team medal counts obscures each athlete’s individual and very human trials and tribulations, focusing on times, records, and outcomes.

In 2006, I was alone on the world stage, and blamed only myself when I fell.

If falling was hard, harder still was walking away.  After two decades spent mastering my sport, I finally hung up my skates and found myself profoundly disoriented as the sense of self I achieved as a result of years of hard work on the ice, quickly disintegrated.

But in the best moments, I was able to transcend place and time, losing myself in the music. I felt the audience on the edge of their seats, cheering me on, and sharing in my triumphs.  My short program in Turin was one of those moments.

All of this played out for me when most young adults are headed off to college, experiencing their first real taste of independence, making lifelong friendships, and charting out what direction their careers might take. Their mistakes won’t be scrutinized in the public eye (at least that was largely the case before social media) and for most, passing final exams is the biggest source of stress.

Part of me wishes that I, too, could have had those rights of passage.

Yet looking back at my life choices, I would absolutely do it all over again. Medaling at the Olympics was the realization of a dream that I had and committed to achieving in a way few people can ever understand. Other than having children, it was the most profound and meaningful part of my life and for that, I would not exchange it for anything.

These days, my world now revolves around two little people — constantly testing boundaries and figuring out who they are. I want my kids to know that accomplishing great things takes work.

I want them to know the priceless triumph of overcoming their fears because they chose to show up, despite the nerves and doubt. But when success is defined by perfection in one particular moment, that’s a tough way to live and it’s not for everyone. It’s a deeply personal and consequential choice.  And yet, I would never want them to miss pursuing their dreams because the cost of admission is too high.

Sasha Cohen is the 2006 Olympic silver medalist, 2006 U.S. Champion, 2003 Grand-Prix Final Champion, and a three-time World medalist. Following her competitve career, she graduated from Columbia University's General Studies and now works as a financial analyst.

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Sasha Cohen knows Olympic dreams come with agony, but she would do it all again

title: Man Utd and Chelsea dispute claims they approached Jurgen Klopp after Liverpool exit
description: Since leaving Liverpool, Jurgen Klopp has been making the most of his break from football management, taking some time to relax away from the touchline. This week, he was seen ringing the bell at the Winter Olympics, continuing to enjoy life without the demands of daily training and matches.
fullText:
Since leaving Liverpool, Jurgen Klopp has been making the most of his break from football management, taking some time to relax away from the touchline.

This week, he was seen ringing the bell at the Winter Olympics, continuing to enjoy life without the demands of daily training and matches.

Despite his intention to step away from management following his 2024 departure from Liverpool, Klopp has still found himself linked to several high-profile jobs.

Recent reports have suggested he could be in line for one of the vacant roles at either Chelsea or Manchester United. There were even claims that both clubs had reached out to his representatives over a possible return.

But according to Fabrizio Romano, both clubs have now denied those rumours.

In a recent update on his YouTube channel, Romano said he has spoken directly with both clubs regarding the speculation.

According to him, while both clubs respect what Klopp has achieved, neither made any formal move to bring him in.

Romano explained: “When contacted, both clubs – Manchester United and Chelsea – are playing down those reports, saying that nothing really happened with Jurgen Klopp apart from the admiration they have for one of the best managers in the world.”

“Both clubs absolutely announce that they never had any advanced or concrete negotiations to appoint Jurgen Klopp.”

Chelsea have already filled their managerial vacancy by hiring Liam Rosenior. But with United still searching for their next manager, it wouldn’t be a surprise if talk about Klopp resurfaces later in the summer.

Real Madrid are another club who could be looking for a permanent manager this summer, having brought in former Liverpool defender Alvaro Arbeloa as an interim coach. Despite the speculation, Romano says there’s nothing developing between Klopp and the Spanish club.

“On the future of Jurgen Klopp, don’t forget that he’s still very busy with the Red Bull project, still focused on that,” he said.

“With Real Madrid, I keep telling you guys, let’s see what happens with Arbeloa because he’s doing a very good job now. Second step, Jurgen Klopp has some people in the Real Madrid board appreciating him a lot, but at the moment I’m not aware of concrete talks. That’s the status as of today.”

Klopp remains one of football’s most respected figures and could likely walk into any role he wanted. But so far, he’s kept to his word about taking time away from coaching.

title: Most valuable franchises in MLB
description: In Major League Baseball, franchise value reflects far more than wins and losses — it represents legacy, market influence, brand power, and the emotional investment of generations of fans. According to Forbes, the sport’s most valuable teams are not just…
fullText:
In Major League Baseball, franchise value reflects far more than wins and losses — it represents legacy, market influence, brand power, and the emotional investment of generations of fans. According to Forbes, the sport’s most valuable teams are not just successful organizations but enduring cultural institutions that shape how baseball is experienced across the country and around the world. Leading the way are iconic brands like the New York Yankees and Los Angeles Dodgers, whose global reach and financial strength mirror their long-standing competitive prominence. Close behind, franchises such as the Boston Red Sox and Chicago Cubs prove that deep-rooted history and passionate fan loyalty can translate into extraordinary economic value. Meanwhile, the San Francisco Giants showcase how sustained success in the modern era can elevate a franchise’s stature both competitively and commercially.

What unites these teams is their ability to transcend the game itself. Each operates as a powerful entertainment brand, drawing massive attendance, commanding lucrative media deals, and maintaining devoted followings that span generations. Their ballparks are destinations, their histories are woven into the fabric of their cities, and their influence stretches well beyond regional markets. In many ways, these franchises serve as pillars of baseball’s identity — setting financial benchmarks while carrying the traditions that keep the sport deeply connected to its past.

Franchise value: $8.2B
Few brands in sports carry the global recognition of the Yankees. Their history is stacked with championships, legends, and iconic moments that shaped baseball itself. The franchise thrives on tradition, star power, and unmatched cultural visibility. Whether contending or rebuilding, they remain baseball’s financial and symbolic powerhouse.

Franchise value: $6.8B
The Dodgers blend historic prestige with modern dominance better than almost anyone. Their massive fan base stretches across Southern California and well beyond, fueled by consistent winning and aggressive investment in talent. The franchise excels both on the field and at the gate, drawing huge attendance year after year. They represent the blueprint for a contemporary big-market contender.

Franchise value: $4.8B
The Red Sox carry one of baseball’s most emotionally charged legacies, rooted deeply in Boston’s identity. From the drama of historic droughts to the euphoria of multiple modern titles, the team lives at the center of passionate fandom. Fenway Park’s atmosphere alone is part of their brand value. Their history, rivalry, and regional loyalty make them perpetually relevant.

Franchise value: $4.6B
The Cubs transformed from lovable underdogs into a global brand, especially after their long-awaited championship breakthrough. Wrigley Field’s charm and neighborhood feel give the franchise a timeless appeal. Generations of fans stayed loyal through decades of heartbreak, strengthening the team’s cultural footprint. Today, they balance nostalgia with modern competitiveness.

Franchise value: $4.0B
The Giants built a 21st-century dynasty that elevated their national profile and market value. Their waterfront ballpark and strong regional following make them a cornerstone of West Coast baseball. Success across multiple championship runs reinforced their reputation for smart roster construction and stability. They embody sustained excellence with a distinctly San Francisco identity.

Together, these franchises represent the gold standard of value in Major League Baseball — where heritage, market strength, and sustained relevance intersect. Their financial dominance reflects decades of cultural impact, smart organizational leadership, and unwavering fan devotion. As the sport continues to evolve, these teams remain defining forces, proving that true franchise value is built not just on performance, but on legacy that endures across generations.

title: Arteta tells faltering leaders Arsenal to harness Wolves 'pain' against Spurs
description: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta has urged his side to use the "pain" of a shock 2-2 draw with Wolves when they look to revive their Premier League title challenge against arch-rivals Tottenham Hotspur.Arsenal are away to struggling Tottenham in a north London derby on Sunday, with Arteta saying: "We need to go through the pain and go through it looking in the mirror and understand what the game requires now and the next action is Sunday.
fullText:
Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta has urged his side to use the "pain" of a shock 2-2 draw with Wolves when they look to revive their Premier League title challenge against arch-rivals Tottenham Hotspur.

The Gunners were on course for a routine win on Wednesday after goals from Bukayo Saka and Piero Hincapie put them 2-0 up at Molineux.

But bottom of the table Wolves hit back through Hugo Bueno and Tom Edozie.

The draw left Arsenal, bidding to end a 22-year-wait to be crowned champions of England again, just five points clear of second-placed Manchester City.

It was the second match in a row where Arsenal had dropped points following a draw with Brentford and meant they have now won just twice in their last seven league games.

City, who have a game in hand, twice chased Arsenal down to win the Premier League in both the 2022/23 and 2023/24 seasons and their April clash with the Gunners could prove pivotal to the title race.

But Arteta said: "I'm going to be the first one to be close with them (the players) because it has nothing to do with attitude or desire, it is completely the opposite.

"It's part of football. Where it could've gone wrong today, it went wrong.

"If you look at the way we conceded the two goals today without conceding any other situations, it is very rare but it happens. And it happened for a reason and we need to react.

"If you are at the top you have to win and win, that's nothing new."

Arsenal are away to struggling Tottenham in a north London derby on Sunday, with Arteta saying: "We need to go through the pain and go through it looking in the mirror and understand what the game requires now and the next action is Sunday. We need to keep all that in our tummies to show it on Sunday."

Meanwhile Saka told Arsenal.com: "It's pretty flat. We're pretty disappointed with the result, it's the only way to describe it.

"I think it's a game of two halves. In the first half we started so well but in the second half we dropped the level and got punished for it."

Looking ahead to the derby match, the England international added: "It was already a big game and now it's still a big game...It's still in our control so we just need to focus on that, fix the issues we're having now and get back to winning ways."

title: Video: Fabregas’ shirt tug and touchline confrontation with Allegri
description: Watch how Cesc Fabregas pulled the shirt of Alexis Saelemaekers and how Milan coach Massimiliano Allegri confronted his counterpart on the sidelines during Wednesday’s Serie A clash.Tension flared d...
fullText:
Watch how Cesc Fabregas pulled the shirt of Alexis Saelemaekers and how Milan coach Massimiliano Allegri confronted his counterpart on the sidelines during Wednesday’s Serie A clash.

Tension flared during Milan-Como on Wednesday, particularly after the visitors’ coach Fabregas tugged on Saelemaekers’ shirt from the sidelines while the game was in progress.

COMO, ITALY – JANUARY 15: Como 1907 coach Cesc Fabregas looks on during the Serie A match between Como 1907 and AC Milan at Giuseppe Sinigaglia Stadium on January 15, 2026 in Como, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Fabregas’ move enraged Allegri, prompting him to confront the Como coach and a staff member, which led to Allegri being shown a red card.

Fabregas apologised at full-time, but Allegri was still upset as he was heard shouting at the Spaniard before a post-match press conference.

MILAN, ITALY – FEBRUARY 18: Massimiliano Allegri, Head Coach of AC Milan, reacts during the Serie A match between AC Milan and Como 1907 at Giuseppe Meazza Stadium on February 18, 2026 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Below are videos of the touchline confrontation and the shirt tug that infuriated Allegri.

#MilanComo In Eccellenza si vedono queste cose? Forse nei campionati colombiani. Guardate il numero di maglia come si deforma! Il quarto uomo cieco. Le scuse post gara di #Fabregas sono ipocrite. Almeno #Allegri gliele ha cantate, perché sanzioni ahimè non ce ne saranno pic.twitter.com/yIlroxcJln

title: Bodo/Glimt 3-1 Inter Milan – Italy Prodigy The Only Shining Light In Otherwise Dark Arctic Night
description: Francesco Pio Esposito produced an impressive performance in last night’s Champions League clash between Bodo/Glimt and Inter Milan.According to Corriere dello Sport via FCInter1908, the 20-year-old...
fullText:
Francesco Pio Esposito produced an impressive performance in last night’s Champions League clash between Bodo/Glimt and Inter Milan.

According to Corriere dello Sport via FCInter1908, the 20-year-old was the only shining light for the visitors.

Inter Milan suffered a dismal 3-1 defeat at the Aspmyra Stadion, casting doubt on their hopes of reaching the Round of 16.

Furthermore, the Nerazzurri lost captain Lautaro Martinez to a ‘serious’ injury, with El Toro leaving the pitch in the second half.

Therefore, Cristian Chivu will likely have to rely on Marcus Thuram to fill the void.

MILAN, ITALY – JANUARY 23: Francesco Pio Esposito of FC Internazionale Milano celebrates scoring his team’s third goal during the Serie A match between FC Internazionale and Pisa SC at Giuseppe Meazza Stadium on January 23, 2026 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Francesco Pio Esposito drew Inter level after Sondre Fet broke the deadlock in the 20th minute.

In doing so, he became the youngest-ever Nerazzurri player to score in the Champions League knockout stages.

However, the youngster’s exploits were in vain as Bodo/Glimt netted two unanswered second-half goals to claim a huge win.

title: Fantasy Baseball starting pitcher rankings for 2026 (1-30)
description: This year’s crop of starting pitchers has a couple of amazing arms that will cost you a first-round pick if you want to roster them, and as much as I hate to say it, taking a pitcher that high is…
fullText:
This year’s crop of starting pitchers has a couple of amazing arms that will cost you a first-round pick if you want to roster them, and as much as I hate to say it, taking a pitcher that high is akin to dancing with the devil in the pale moonlight.  The same two pitchers were the top two off the board last year, so the waters may seem safe, but beware.  Those same waters seemed safe two years ago when Spencer Strider was the top arm off the board. Here are the top 30 SP right now in fantasy baseball:

Two straight Cy Young awards should be reason enough, but at age 29 and playing for what should be the largest ever free agent contract for a pitcher doesn’t hurt either.  The Tigers are sticking with him at the top of their rotation as they make a run for it all in 2026, but don’t be surprised if he’s dealt to a contender if Detroit isn’t competitive.  He’s basically guaranteed to be pitching for a contender for the entire season.

MORE: Fantasy Baseball 2026 Catcher Rankings (16-30)

The Pirates have improved their offense from last year, so it’s possible we get more than the 10 wins from Skenes that we got last year.  Even without the wins, he dominates batters to such an extent that we can comfortably project him to have an era. at or below 2.00.  Flip a coin between these top 2 pitchers, I can’t be mad at either one going before the other.

Crochet basically sits on a tier by himself as the #3 pitcher in the league.  He eclipsed 200 innings last year after setting a career high in 2024 with 146.  The comparisons to Chris Sale are mostly due to his left-handedness and his tall beanpole physique, but there is also the concern over workload issues, as he was a relief pitcher just 3 years ago.  He’s a great pick, but he makes me nervous.  I don’t wish injuries on anybody, but this guy is already a one-time TJS survivor.

Woo is another young gun who emerged as a bona fide ace last year, finishing 5th in the AL Cy Young award voting.  His innings have been ramping up over the past 3 years, so I’m not quite as worried about him as I am Crochet.  If you take him, he’s going to cost you a more tolerable late 3rd round or early 4th round pick, and he’s a great anchor for your pitching staff.  You will also get to enjoy a full season of doing your best Ric Flair impressions every time he pitches.

The Mariners have a good pitching staff, in case you haven’t noticed.  Gilbert missed a month and a half of last season with a flexor strain but still managed to pile up over 170 Ks in just 131 innings.  He had posted 3 straight seasons heading into 2025 of 180+ innings, so he should be safe to get back to that total (barring another injury, of course).  He’s going right around the same spot as Woo in early drafts.

He was a stud last year, especially in the postseason, where he basically pitched in every game of the World Series. My only slight concern with him (as well as with all Dodger pitchers) is the fact that the team is on a mission to win yet another title, and they don’t care about our fantasy teams.  He won’t likely make 30 starts this year as Ohtani will be a two-way player for the whole season, and they will likely be using a 6-man rotation.  Set your expectations for 26 starts and about 160 innings, and you won’t be disappointed.

He became the de facto Yankee ace in the absence of Gerrit Cole last season and answered the call by finishing 4th in the AL Cy Young voting.  His 195 innings were a career high, and he has had a history of arm issues that have landed him on the IR over his career.  Expecting a repeat of last year might be a bit ambitious, but he’s still going to put up great numbers as long as he can post.

This guy just keeps doing it year in and year out.  In a time where it’s rare to find a pitcher who is able to give you 180 innings, Webb has AVERAGED over 200 innings per season over the last 4 years.  He’s still just 29, and he’s a great anchor to start your staff if you wait until the 4th round or so to take your first pitcher.  His spike in K rate can be attributed to his reliance more on his sweeper over his sinker and using his changeup more selectively as more of an out pitch to put batters away.  These numbers are in line with how he used his repertoire back in 2021 when he last averaged over 9 k/9, so it’s very possible that he stays with this approach going forward.

There was a lot to love about the 2025 season for Sanchez as he was the unanimous #2 pitcher in the NL last year, to Paul Skenes according to Cy Young voters.   He was one of only 3 pitchers to throw for over 200 innings, and it wasn’t much of a bump for him from 2024, when he threw 181, so we’re not too worried about overusage.  He’ll cost you a mid-third round pick, but I still like him just behind Webb, who has been going later.  If he’s there and Webb isn’t, I’ll jump on him to start my fantasy pitching staff.

He’s been one of the best pitchers in the game since May 2024.  His 2.43 era in 2026 was right in line with the 2.51 era he posted from May 1 on in 2024.  His 10.0 k/9 ranked him as the 10th-best strikeout pitcher amongst starters, and his 206 Ks ranked 8th in all of baseball.  The bottom line?  He’s an ace for the Astros, and he will be an ace for your fantasy team.  He’s a bargain in the early 4th round.

Greene is this high based on pure ability, but that ability has been more of a tease than a league winner to this point in his career.  He has yet to throw for over 160 innings in any of his 4 major league seasons, but his K rate era. and ratio numbers over the last 2 years are quite inspiring.  If he can manage 180 innings, he’s going to be a Cy Young Award finalist.  He’s a rare breed of pitcher that can excel even while pitching in that bandbox in Cincinnati.

He was able to put the best parts of his previous two seasons together in 2025 as he had a career year for the Twins with 194 Ks in 171 innings pitched, along with a 3.42 era and a 1.07 whip.  Entering the season at 29 years of age, he’s poised to retain his mantle as the Twins ace and should be their opening day starter.  He’s an excellent #2 for your fantasy team and a fine #1 if you decide to wait on pitching for a few rounds.  He’s going after guys like deGrom and Sale, but in deeper leagues, I’d much prefer the younger Ryan.

Much like Hunter Greene, Sale has put up elite numbers without playing a full season.  Unlike Greene, Sale is on the wrong side of 30, and the likelihood of him reaching even as many as 25 starts seems like a stretch.  When he does pitch, he’s one of the best in the game. Just be aware that you aren’t buying a full season’s worth of stats.  He has much more value in a shallower league where decent replacements are available when he’s not.

If you can’t get Sale, why not get his twin?  DeGrom somehow managed to throw 172 innings last year.  Are we seriously betting on that happening again?  No.  If we were, he’d be much higher on this list after posting a 2.97 era with a sub-1 WHIP along with 185 Ks last year.  Much like Sale, deGrom is elite when he pitches, just don’t buy him expecting a repeat of last year’s numbers.  Much like Sale, he’s a great option for shallower leagues.  If somebody else wants to use their 3rd round pick on him, let them.  It won’t be me.

No matter what you may think about him, he’s been a workhorse over his career, averaging 30 starts and throwing at least 175+ innings over his last 4 seasons.  Now calling pitcher-friendly Comerica Park his home, his sinker-heavy approach should make him one of the toughest pitchers in the game to take deep.  It remains to be seen how Detroit’s patchwork infield will hold things down behind him, but he’s a solid bet to post 180 innings with about the same number of strikeouts.  He’s a great #2 for any fantasy or real-life staff.

He was a favorite sleeper of mine heading into 2025, and he outperformed my lofty expectations.  The K rate bounced back to his 2022-23 levels while he was in Miami and playing for a better team juiced up his win total.  The era took a bit of a step back, but that can be chalked up to the move from pitcher-friendly Marlins Park to Citizens Bank Park.  At just 28 years of age, with full health, he can take another step this year and give Skenes some competition for that CYA.

The Mets new ace has New York fans buzzing as he brings a resume that includes three straight years of 30+ starts and 200+ Ks to Flushing for 2026.  He needs to figure out how to consistently go 6 innings if he’s going to take that next step to the land of the truly elite.  Even where he is right now, he’s in rarified air, so buy him banking on what he’s been doing, and keep your fingers crossed that there’s even 

He was a hot target last season after finishing 4th in the AL Cy Young voting in 2024, earning him the opening day nod for the Royals.  He came out of the gate sluggish and ended up on the IL after just 6 starts.  The injury cost him most of the season, and upon his return, it took him a few starts to get right.  Over 3 short starts in September, he looked to be the pitcher we were hoping for with 22 Ks over 13 innings with a 2.77 era.  He might be a bit of a reach this high, but I believe in the talent as well as his

He’s been a workhorse, but now he’s a 35-year-old workhorse.  He has posted 31+ starts and 170+ innings in every season since 2021 and will remain atop the Blue Jays rotation for the upcoming season.  He likely has one more season in him at this level, but at this age, anything can happen (just ask Zack Wheeler).  The skills are still there, so as long as he keeps toeing the rubber, he’s going to be a fantasy asset.

A shoulder injury messed with the beginning of his season, and once he returned, he wasn’t quite able to match his previous surface numbers.  Looking beneath the surface, his velocity was the same as pre-injury, and his K rate actually increased.  I’m willing to buy in at a discount if I can get it and expect a return to 2024 at minimum.  Entering his age-28 season, there’s potential for another step forward with full health.

If you are a fan of trends, then this is the year to grab Dylan Cease.  He’s been a lock for 200+ Ks every year for 5 straight seasons, but his era and whip have bounced up and down every year.  The trend would suggest that this year he’s due for improvement over the 4.55 and 1.33 rates from last year and another top 5 CYA finish.  His stuff is so nasty that I don’t think a move from San Diego to Toronto will matter very much.  He’s the epitome of a “one skill away” pitcher who might just win that CYA this year if he puts it all together.

He’s going to be a full two-way player this year for the Dodgers, but what does that mean for fantasy?  If you are playing in a league where you can only draft “One Shohei”, then you are likely drafting him to fill your DH role.  In that case, you can stop reading since he’s long gone by now.  If you are in a league that rosters Shohei the hitter and Shohei the pitcher as two different players, he makes for an interesting pitching option.  We can’t really draft him much higher than this because we can’t assume he will make many more than 20-25 starts.  Using his 2023 numbers with the Angels as the baseline, this is a good spot to take him.

The story has always been the same with Snell.  He’s an amazing talent, but he struggles to stay healthy, and he throws too many pitches to go deep into games.  He’s in the absolute perfect rotation, so he’ll be protected and won’t have to pile up innings.  The downside is he won’t pile up stats, so pay for 120-140 innings max.  On the bright side, he has shown he can amass 170+ strikeouts with under 130 innings pitched.

He missed all of 2024 with a shoulder injury, and last year, he suffered a few setbacks that delayed his arrival to the mound for the Crew.  Once he did return, he was back in peak form…..until another injury ended his season.  The injury that ended his 2025 was unrelated to the shoulder, and he’s entering camp at full strength, so I feel pretty good about him, even as he enters his age-33 season.  Buy in and bank on 130 innings as a baseline, and you won’t be disappointed.

He’s 36 years old now and has moved from St. Louis to Boston after back-to-back seasons of 200+ strikeouts for the Redbirds.  His era has been up and down over the last 5 years, and at 36 years of age, I don’t know if we can buy in expecting a bounce back.  The age always scares me, but if you can get him at a fair price (after the 8th round) he’s worth the add.

Based on last year’s numbers, he should be higher on this list, but at 33 years of age, he’s never exactly been the model of consistency.  2025 was likely a career year for Pivetta, and I hate paying the full price for a season that likely won’t ever happen again.  Not only was his 2.87 era his career best, but it was also the first time in his career he pitched to an era under 4.  His underlying skills always suggested that he was due for improvement, but I don’t think we can buy into a repeat of last year.  If everybody is thinking the same way and he falls, I’ll be happy to take him here.  Just don’t count on much more than 150 innings, 160ish K’s, and a mid-3 era.

He’s young, and the skills say a break-out is coming.  It’s just a matter of staying healthy.  After missing all of 2024 with Tommy John Surgery, he struggled a bit to begin last year before finishing strong.  At just 23 years of age, he should be good to put up closer to 150 innings this year, and I think he’s a strong bet to post 175 Ks with a mid-3 era and low whip.  In keeper leagues, bump him up a little bit because 2027 might be a monster for him.

He was well on his way to establishing himself as a top-of-the-rotation anchor for Baltimore after a strong 2023, where he posted a K per inning over 168 frames with a sub-3 ERA.  Tommy John got him 8 starts into 2024, and when he finally made it back last year, he looked as good as ever.  Now at full strength entering his age-29 season, he’s poised to lead the Orioles rotation this year.  His K rate from the portions of 24-25′ suggests that there is a step forward coming.

Another piece (#4 so far) of this elite Mariner rotation.  He’s older now (33), and he’s not quite what he used to be, but he’s still very good.  He won’t likely give us the 200+ Ks that he did back in 2023, but he’s a solid bet to take his turn in the rotation 30+ times and give us 180 innings, 165 Ks with double-digit wins and solid rate stats.  He’s not super sexy, but he’s a solid pick in the later middle rounds of your draft.

He’s sort of the 6th Beatle, but the truth is, he might very well end up being the best of the bunch.  He missed all of 2024 after receiving the internal brace version of TJS, and upon his return, he gave the Dodgers 12 very nice starts (15 total appearances) where he totaled 89 Ks in 73.1 IP with a 2.82 era and a sterling 0.97 WHIP.  Then, when the postseason rolled around, he went to the bullpen.  That’s going to be the issue this year.  He’s not going to get 30 starts, but if he can get us 25, he’s well worth a pick in about the 10th round in mixed leagues.

title: Sidney Crosby injury update: Canada men’s hockey captain not ruled out at Olympics
description: Sidney Crosby suffered an injury to his right leg during Canada's Olympics quarterfinal and had to leave the game against Czechia.
fullText:
MILAN — In the immediate aftermath of Sidney Crosby leaving a game because of injury, Jon Cooper said he didn't know Crosby's status and noted, "I don't even have my poker face on."

It was back on the next day, as Cooper declined to give a definitive answer on the status of Canada's men's hockey team captain, who did not partake in an optional practice on Feb. 19. However, Cooper did not rule him out for the remainder of the 2026 Winter Olympics, which at most would be two games. Canada plays a semifinal game against Finland on Feb. 20 at Milan Santagiulia Ice Hockey Arena. Win or lose, there's a medal game next.

"Sid is by no means ruled out of the tournament," Cooper said. "We’ve got the best of the best looking at him. We’re taking this day by day. And we’re not going to put anyone in harm’s way. But if he can play, he’s definitely going to. We’ll know 

Canada needed overtime to advance out of a quarterfinal match against Czechia, and had to make do for more than half of it without Crosby.

Crosby was injured on a hard hit from Czechia's Radko Gudas, with Crosby's right leg buckling as he went down. He was also crunched by Martin Necas. Crosby hobbled to Canada's bench, then down the tunnel, and did not return.

Instead, he addressed his teammates during the second intermission, when it was 2-2, essentially urging them to go get the victory.

"There was a lot more than that," Cooper said. "You know, he's a true leader."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Sidney Crosby injury update: Canada’s hockey captain not ruled out at Olympics

title: Gloucester bring in Braley for cup game
description: Unattached scrum-half Callum Braley set to return for Gloucester on Friday in the Prem Rugby Cup.
fullText:
Callum Braley is set to make his second Gloucester debut in Friday's Prem Rugby Cup game against Sale after rejoining the club on a short-term deal.

Braley, 31, spent six years with the Cherry and Whites and made more than 100 appearances before leaving for Benetton in 2020.

He has been training with the club since January, and after being re-registered he has been named on the bench for Friday's match, following an injury to number nine Mike Austin.

"He came in the building in January, he's back in the local area, he felt he had unfinished business with the game and wanted to make sure that he didn't leave it early," Gloucester scrum and assistant forwards coach Trevor Woodman told BBC Radio Gloucestershire.

Exeter thump Gloucester; Leicester and Bath win in Cup

Mortgage advisor to Gloucester hooker - Crane's big step up

Bristol-born Braley has 15 international caps for the Azzurri, qualifying through his Italian grandfather.

But after two years with the United Rugby Championship side he returned to the UK and has struggled to pin down a permanent club.

He spent two seasons with Northampton, but made just 18 appearances - and only two during 2023-24.

Short-term stints at Saracens and Cardiff followed last season but again resulted in just one outing for each club.

"Having his experience training with us the last six weeks has been great," Woodman added.

"I think he's just loved the fact he can come back in, follow a schedule. He's always a fit character anyway, so just being in and around a group again, those things are really important.

"Whether you've unfortunately been forced out of the game through no opportunities for you or you're coming to retirement, but being in and around a group of players is good for you on two fronts - mentally and physically - so I think he's loved it."

Gloucester go into the game against the Sharks off the back of a 48-14 defeat by Exeter, to leave them third in the group with two games to go.

title: 2026 NFL combine preview: Which running backs were invited?
description: With the NFL combine near, here is a look at which running backs were invited and a positional breakdown from the Indianapolis Colts' perspective.
fullText:
The NFL combine begins soon, running from Feb. 23 to March 2. To preview this important pre-draft event, we will be taking a position-by-position look at which prospects were invited and the level of need that the Indianapolis Colts have at each spot.

The NFL combine is held at Lucas Oil Stadium and is an opportunity for the top NFL draft prospects in this year’s class to go through measurements and various on-field drills, some of which are specific to their position group, and others measure the player’s overall athleticism.

For NFL teams, this event is another data point for them as they build out their draft profiles and big boards. However, it’s a significant data point, with players potentially flying up and down draft boards depending on how they perform.

In addition to the on-field drills, teams also get the opportunity to meet with players one-on-one as well, which is another important part of the evaluation process as they get to know them both on and off the field.

Taylor is still under contract through 2026, so the need remains relatively low. With Taylor still just 27 years old, he could be a potential contract extension candidate this offseason.

However, while the need at running back may not be high, the Colts could still make an addition here. Adding an inexpensive veteran option in free agency or a mid to late round pick in the draft to bolster the depth and competition behind Taylor could be on Chris Ballard's radar.

Bentley was on the practice squad last season, and Giddens was often inactive, still needing to develop parts of his game, particularly in pass protection.

This article originally appeared on Colts Wire: Indianapolis Colts' 2026 NFL combine preview: running backs

title: Turki Alalshikh unveils Zuffa Boxing belt as fans brand it ‘ugly’
description: Boxing fans are sharing their thoughts on the introduction of yet another new title belt. When Dana White introduced Zuffa Boxing earlier this year, he said he wanted to bring real change to the sport.
fullText:
Boxing fans are sharing their thoughts on the introduction of yet another new title belt.

When Dana White introduced Zuffa Boxing earlier this year, he said he wanted to bring real change to the sport.

Now, White has followed through on that idea by creating a brand-new world title that will be unique to Zuffa Boxing.

Boxing promoter Eddie Hearn called the move ‘cringe’, and fans concur after seeing the belt.

Turki Alalshikh took to social media on Wednesday to share a photo of the new Zuffa Boxing championship belt.

He was joined in the picture by White and Nick Khan, both key figures in the promotion.

“Today I am happy, I met with my brothers Dana and Nick in Las Vegas, and they gifted me the first Zuffa Boxing belt – made with beautiful diamonds,” Alashikh posted on X.

“This is a huge start for Zuffa, and only the very best will be lucky enough to win this belt.”

Even though comments were turned off on his post, there were still plenty of reactions elsewhere online.

Fans reacted quickly to the new design, and the response was far from positive.

“That belt is awful,” one fan wrote in response to a Ring Magazine’s tweet.

Another added: “The ugliest belt in the history of boxing.”

A third person chimed in: “I support Zuffa boxing, but that belt is terrible… they need to redesign it ASAP.”

“Looks cheap like a costume belt you buy at the toy store,” someone else wrote.

A fifth simply said: “The belt sucks, and so does the name.”

A sixth fan tweeted: “That’s the worst-looking belt I’ve ever seen.”

Jake Paul once joked about fighting Ronda Rousey in old video before his boxing debut

10 years before signing Ronda Rousey to MVP, Jake Paul wanted to ‘fight’ the former UFC champion

title: Liam Lawson faces difficulties at Racing Bulls as 2026 F1 rules could expose driving flaws
description: Liam Lawson has been cautioned that the new 2026 Formula 1 cars might bring to light a weakness in his game this season. The Racing Bulls haven’t had a standout pre-season so far, but Arvid Lindblad did manage to put in more laps than anyone else during Wednesday’s morning session.
fullText:
Liam Lawson has been cautioned that the new 2026 Formula 1 cars might bring to light a weakness in his game this season.

The Racing Bulls haven’t had a standout pre-season so far, but Arvid Lindblad did manage to put in more laps than anyone else during Wednesday’s morning session.

He handed over driving duties to Liam Lawson for the afternoon as both drivers get ready for the season opener in Australia.

Jack Doohan, watching from trackside in Bahrain, noticed something in the Racing Bulls setup that could be an issue going forward. Still, team principal Alan Permane will hope there’s enough time to address any problems with the VCARB 03 before racing gets underway.

Meanwhile, commentator and journalist Nelson Valkenburg believes a familiar problem could return for Lawson. He suggested that issues from his short spell at Red Bull might reappear this year with the new regulations:

Valkenburg spoke about Racing Bulls’ performance during an appearance on the Nailing the Apex Podcast and said: “Yes, it felt very uninterested in headline lap times, but they had some performance niggles and some engine problems and hydraulics.

“I don’t know, where the foundation of the Red Bull feels incredibly strong and stable, less so for the Racing Bulls team, but we can put them in this similar category [to Audi]. Could be fifth, could be eighth.

“I’m becoming a fan of Lindblad. When I spoke to him, he didn’t look shell-shocked, and that’s a good place to be after your first few test days.

“For Lawson, I worry a bit simply because we’ve learned over these days that there is a way of going fast into corners that makes the car a little tail happy.

“Which is probably a nightmare scenario for Liam Lawson, considering what we saw at Red Bull last year.

“You go through the gears, your weight transfers to the front, you do a lot of engine braking and the car. You have to hang on to the rear as you turn into the corner; basically Max’s dream right?”

While there are certainly areas for concern when it comes to Racing Bulls’ chances this season based on what has been seen during pre-season testing so far in Bahrain. However they’ll hope that they still have time before things get going for real against McLaren in Australia next month.

While the early feedback on the new regulations hasn’t been overwhelmingly positive for Lawson, he’s still young enough to develop the skills needed to thrive under these conditions.

Racing Bulls clearly believe in his potential – they wouldn’t have chosen him over Yuki Tsunoda if they didn’t think he could be a strong partner for Lindblad.

On the first day of Bahrain’s second week of testing, Lawson finished 12th, seven places ahead of Lindblad.

The times don’t hold much weight at this point in the season, but it’s still a small boost for Lawson as he heads into the final stretch of pre-season preparations.

Ferrari’s F1 car struggles with Verstappen’s high-revs downshift trick during Bahrain test

Carlos Alcaraz says what he thinks about Formula 1 after watching Bahrain test

Anthony Davidson accuses Fernando Alonso of ‘burning up’ tyres in Aston Martin during F1 testing

title: Real Madrid issue fresh statement as Uefa investigates Vinicius Jr’s racism allegation
description: Vinicius Jr claimed that he was racially abused by Benfica’s Gianluca Prestianni during Tuesday’s Champions League match
fullText:
Real Madrid has submitted "all available evidence" to Uefa as the governing body investigates allegations of racism made by their forward Vinicius Junior.

The move comes after the Brazilian star reported racial abuse during a Champions League knockout round play-off tie in Lisbon.

Vinicius Junior claims he reported the abuse, allegedly from Benfica winger Gianluca Prestianni, to referee Francois Letexier during Tuesday’s match.

Uefa confirmed on Wednesday that it had launched a disciplinary investigation into the events.

In a statement, Real Madrid confirmed their cooperation: "Real Madrid CF announces that it has today provided Uefa with all available evidence regarding the incidents that occurred (on) Tuesday, February 17, during the Champions League match that our team played in Lisbon against SL Benfica."

The club added, "Our club has actively co-operated with the investigation opened by Uefa following the unacceptable episodes of racism experienced during that match."

The Spanish giants also expressed gratitude for the support shown to their player.

"Real Madrid is grateful for the unanimous support and affection that our player Vinicius Jr. has received from all sectors of the global football community," the statement continued.

"Real Madrid will continue working, in collaboration with all institutions, to eradicate racism, violence and hatred in sport and in society."

The match was temporarily halted for 10 minutes in line with UEFA regulations after Vinicius reported the abuse following his goal celebration. He was subsequently shown a yellow card for the celebration.

Following the game, Vinicius took to Instagram, writing in Portuguese: "Racists are, above all, cowards. They need to put their shirts in their mouths to demonstrate how weak they are. But they have protection from others who, theoretically, have the obligation to punish.

“Nothing that happened today is new in my life and my family’s. I received a yellow card for celebrating a goal. Still not understanding why. On the other side, just a poorly executed protocol that served no purpose."

Prestianni has since denied making any racist comments towards Vinicius via his own Instagram account. Benfica, his club, has also criticised what they termed a "defamation campaign" against their player.

Adding to the controversy, Benfica coach Jose Mourinho has faced criticism from anti-discrimination charity Kick It Out, which described his post-match comments as "gaslighting."

Mourinho told Amazon Prime: "I told (Vinicius), when you score a goal like that you just celebrate and walk back. They (Vinicius and Prestianni) told me different things. But I don’t believe in one or another. I want to be an independent."

He further remarked that "something happens, always" in matches featuring Vinicius.

title: Former OU staffer promoted at Big Ten program
description: A former Oklahoma Sooners support staff member has earned a promotion with the Washington Huskies.
fullText:
Former Oklahoma Sooners assistant director of player personnel JP Losman left the program last offseason to get back to an on-field role, and it's a move that paid off, as he's earned a promotion this week.

Losman spent three seasons at OU, but served as the assistant quarterbacks coach at Washington last year. After head coach Jedd Fisch and the Huskies parted ways with offensive coordinator/quarterbacks coach Jimmie Doughtery, they made the decision to promote Losman to quarterbacks coach, according to a report from ESPN's Adam Rittenberg.

Losman aided in the development of star UW quarterback Demond Williams Jr., and he has extensive experience playing the position as well. He played his college ball at Tulane, where he served as a two-year starter in 2002 and 2003.

— Adam Rittenberg (@ESPNRittenberg) February 18, 2026

After being a first-round pick in the 2004 NFL Draft by the Buffalo Bills, he also played for the Oakland Raiders, Seattle Seahawks, and Miami Dolphins. His coaching career began at Clemson in 2017 and Brent Venables brought him to Norman in 2022. Losman's wife, Zulaikha, was also on staff with the Sooners during the same timeframe he was. She served as OU's director of SOUL mission, player/parent relations.

Losman's time with the Seahawks saw him partner with Fisch, who is the Huskies' offensive play-caller. Washington is still searching for a new offensive coordinator.

For the Sooners, they have replaced three position coaches already this offseason. OU officially announced the hiring of tight ends coach Jason Witten, and Oklahoma is reported to be hiring LaMar Morgan to coach defensive backs and Deland McCullough to coach running backs.

Contact/Follow us @SoonersWire on X, and like our page on Facebook to follow ongoing coverage of Oklahoma news, notes, and opinions. You can also follow Aaron on X@Aaron_Gelvin.

This article originally appeared on Sooners Wire: Former Oklahoma staff member earns promotion at Big Ten school

title: How Szoboszlai became Liverpool's key man
description: Inside the Hungarian midfielder's season as the main character at Liverpool, his friendship with Mohamed Salah and why the Reds are keen to extend his contract.
fullText:
On his forearm, Dominik Szoboszlai has a tattoo in Hungarian which reads 'Talent is a divine blessing, but without incredible will and humility, it is worth nothing'.

Dig a little deeper and you find the quote is attributed to Steven Gerrard.

When midfielder Szobozlai arrived at Liverpool from RB Leipzig in 2023 for £60m, there was a reason why he took the number eight shirt that had become synonymous with Gerrard at Anfield.

Earlier that summer, Alexis Mac Allister turned down the chance to take the number, but Szoboszlai craved that main-character energy.

The 25-year-old has been Liverpool's main character this season, scoring his 10th goal of the season last weekend, to go with seven assists.

When it was put to him that he was having a "Steven Gerrard season", he politely disagreed and insisted he was writing his own story.

Only forward Hugo Ekitike has more goal involvements and captain Virgil van Dijk has played more minutes than Szoboszlai for Liverpool this season - and close friend Mohamed Salah described him as "one of the best players in the world right now".

The Hungary international may insist on being his own man, but when it comes to taking responsibility as others struggle, and having his own goal of the season competition at the club, there are certainly similarities to the iconic and inspirational Gerrard.

Szoboszlai hasn't always played in his preferred number 10 position this season, but is scoring more frequently - his stunning free-kicks against Arsenal and Manchester City came in games he started at right-back. The step-up in both consistency and output has been clear.

In a tumultuous Liverpool campaign that has involved speculation about the future of Salah and defenders Ibrahima Konate and Andy Robertson, perhaps the most important negotiation will be with Szoboszlai, who has just over two years to run on the initial five-year deal signed in 2023.

Spanish outlet Marca reported comments last week from Hungary boss Marco Rossi in which he said Szoboszlai's one dream was to play for Real Madrid. The club's Brazilian forward Vinicius Jr also named the Hungary captain as one of his closest friends outside Real.

Encouragingly for Liverpool supporters, talks over a new contract have started, and Szoboszlai said earlier this month he loved the city and the club. His agent, Matyas Esterhazy, added this week on Hungarian TV the player was not looking for a move elsewhere.

Those who see him on a daily basis at Liverpool describe him as highly competitive with a clear desire to excel.

Szoboszlai is regularly among the first to arrive at training and it's no surprise he's high up in terms of the club's running and physical stats. No Liverpool player has covered more distance this season.

In a recent video on Liverpool's channels, Milos Kerkez - who plays with him for club and country - said Szoboszlai would be a 400m runner if he wasn't a footballer.

"He could jog from Liverpool to Hungary and not get tired," joked left-back Kerkez.

Szoboszlai is a man determined in his own right, but Salah's high standards are understood to have a big influence on him. Away from football, the pair enjoy playing backgammon and often hang out together at each other's houses.

When he was described as "disrespectful" last month by Barnsley boss Conor Hourihane for attempting a backheel in his own box that led to a mistake and goal for the League One side, Szoboszlai spoke up to defend himself.

Privately, manager Arne Slot had a word too.

Szoboszlai's prime years are ahead of him. He was handed the national team captaincy at 22 and Liverpool view him as a future skipper, just like Gerrard.

With vice-captain Robertson expected to depart this summer and Van Dijk's deal expiring in 2027, the possibility is certainly there.

Asked if Szoboszlai has the attributes to be a future leader, Slot said: "Yes, but he is still young. He has a lot of attributes already, especially when it comes to leading by example. There is still a step to make in terms of leadership, being vocal and a voice in the dressing room if I compare him to Virgil, which is completely normal.

"Virgil is 34 and has seen [James] Milner, [Jordan] Henderson and these players, so it's really good for Dominik that he sees Virgil. That would be the next step for him; to be as vocal and as loud as Virgil but that comes with time.

"But for all the other things, he has a lot to become a very influential player for Liverpool and you could call that a leader."

During his first season at Liverpool which was Jurgen Klopp's last campaign, Szoboszlai struggled in a game at Luton, and his frustrations summed up when he booted a ball outside the stadium.

Szoboszlai returned later that summer with a point to prove and has been ever-present under Slot since - 2025 was the year he became a husband, father and a Premier League winner.

This term, he has already played more minutes for Liverpool than he did in 2023-24 and only 302 minutes short of matching his tally for the previous campaign.

"Obviously he has been very good [this season]," added Van Dijk. "He's also a player who I think can still make the next step in terms of being a leader for this team. It starts by leading by example and that's something he has done so far this season.

"But also everything around it, there is still progress to be made and that's a good thing in my opinion, so hopefully he will be very important for the years to come at Liverpool."

When Klopp signed Szoboszlai - who had impressed at Red Bull Salzburg before joining RB Leipzig in 2021 - he said: "This is a signing for our present and also for our future."

Liverpool will be keen to make sure that remains the case.

title: Chelsea still favourites for £100m star despite Tottenham’s change of strategy
description: Morgan Rogers has long been touted as a Chelsea transfer target, and he’s a top player. Tottenham are now being linked as well.While there’s plenty of season left, it’s no surprise to see attent...
fullText:
Morgan Rogers has long been touted as a Chelsea transfer target, and he’s a top player. Tottenham are now being linked as well.

While there’s plenty of season left, it’s no surprise to see attentions turn to the summer. Chelsea will likely look to add another attacking options, and a very popular choice among fans would be Morgan Rogers. The Aston Villa attacker has long been linked with us, and looks a world class star.

Now Tottenham are also being mentioned in connection with the 23 year old. Football Insider report that Spurs could look to be more aggressive in the market now they have new people in charge. After a heavy spend last summer, they’d still likely have to sell, but we can see why Rogers is a popular option.

Morgan Rogers in action for Aston Villa. (Photo by Stuart Franklin/Getty Images)

We have our doubts about whether Chelsea will be signing Rodgers, as the reported demands of around £100m just make it such a hard deal to do. But if we make it into the Champions League and Liam Rosenior is really happy with the squad, we can see perhaps one big spend in the summer.

One thing we don’t forsee is Tottenham being the ones to buy him. They’ve even less likely to spend that sort of money, and they’re a far less tempting destination for a player right now. Frankly, it looks most likely he spends another year at Villa right now.

Liam Delap continues to be linked with a move away from Stamford Bridge, but we really don’t see it as likely just yet.

It looks like Marc Cucurella could be missing for a while, so Chelsea fans are wondering about what possible solutions there could be at left back.

Check out the latest edition of Simon Phillips’ SPTC podcast here:

title: Ranji Trophy: Karnataka lead by 802 runs
description: Karnataka dominated Day 4, bundling out Uttarakhand for 233 and then extending their lead to 802 runs in their second innings. With KL Rahul scoring an unbeaten 70, Karnataka effectively booked their Ranji Trophy final spot, focusing on preparation for their title clash.
fullText:
Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel. 

Uttarakhand, resuming at 149/5, were bundled out for 233 in 90 minutes. Karnataka, instead of enforcing the follow-on, chose to rest their bowlers and give their batters time in the middle.

The day began with Karnataka snuffing out Uttarakhand’s resistance swiftly. In reply, Karnataka opened with Mayank Agarwal (21) and Kruthik Krishna (52). Mayank fell at the stroke of lunch, edging Abhay Negi to wicketkeeper Saurabh Rawat. The post-lunch session saw a brief wobble as Shreyas Gopal (0) and Karun Nair (8) departed in quick succession, momentarily slowing the tempo.

Kruthik, however, continued his impressive run, bringing up his second successive half-century. But just as he looked set for more, he misread Avneesh Sudha’s googly and was trapped in front. From there, R Smaran and KL Rahul combined to toy with an increasingly weary Uttarakhand attack. Rahul raced to 70 not out off just 67 balls, with three fours and five sixes. He signalled his half-century by launching a Negi delivery into the long-on stands. For now, Kar-nataka’s focus remains clear — complete the formalities and prepare for one final push at a long-awaited ninth title. The final is likely to be staged at the KSCA Rajnagar Stadium in Hubballi.

Brief scores: Karnataka 736 in 194 overs (Smaran 135, Patil 54; Rawat 4-154, Mishra 3-173) & 299/6 (Smaran 127, Rahul 70;) vs Uttarakhand 233 (Raichandani 55, Rawat 45, V Patil 3-40).

title: Kinghorn & Van der Merwe return for Scots in Wales
description: Scotland head coach Gregor Townsend names Blair Kinghorn and Duhan van der Merwe in the backs as two of five changes for Saturday's Six Nations meeting with Wales.
fullText:
Scotland head coach Gregor Townsend has named Blair Kinghorn and Duhan van der Merwe in the backs for Saturday's Six Nations meeting with Wales in Cardiff.

Kinghorn's return at full-back and Scotland's record try scorer Van der Merwe's place on the wing are two of five changes made by Townsend following last Saturday's victory in the Calcutta Cup.

In the pack, Dave Cherry is in at hooker, Max Williamson takes up a place in the second row and Matt Fagerson joins the back row, with Gregor Brown moving from four to six.

Full-back Tom Jordan and hooker George Turner drop to the bench, while Jack Dempsey, Jamie Dobie and Jamie Ritchie miss out after being ruled out earlier this week.

The Scots opened with a loss in Italy before a convincing win over England.

Neither Toulouse and British and Irish Lions full-back Kinghorn, with 146 points from 60 caps, nor Edinburgh and Lions wing Van der Merwe with 170 points in 50 appearances, featured in the first two Tests.

Costelow and Hamer-Webb start for Wales v Scotland

Replacements: George Turner, Pierre Schoeman, Elliot Millar Mills, Grant Gilchrist, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Tom Jordan, Darcy Graham.

title: VfB Stuttgart boss describes Celtic as most challenging play-off opponent
description: VfB Stuttgart boss Sebastian Hoeness has described Celtic as the most challenging opponent his team could have drawn…Head coach Sebastian Hoeness of VfB Stuttgart looks on during the Bundesliga matc...
fullText:
Head coach Sebastian Hoeness of VfB Stuttgart looks on during the Bundesliga match between FC St. Pauli and VfB Stuttgart at Millerntor Stadium on February 07, 2026 in Hamburg, Germany. (Photo by Selim Sudheimer/Getty Images)

The Bundesliga outfit travel to Glasgow for tonight’s Europa League knockout play-off first leg, with the Scottish champions arriving in fine form after five consecutive wins.

Meanwhile, Stuttgart head into the clash sitting fourth in the Bundesliga, having claimed five victories from their last six matches. Hoeness is also relishing the chance to experience the atmosphere at Celtic Park once again, nearly a decade after his previous visit.

A view of Celtic Park Celtic v Livingston, Scottish Premiership, Celtic Park, 11 February 2026. Photo Mark Runnacles IMAGO/ Shutterstock

The 43-year-old was present in the stadium during his time as a Bayern Munich youth coach, watching as Bayern defeated Celtic 2-1 in the Champions League back in 2017.

Speaking via Daily Record, Hoeness said: “I expect a lot. I think they are a team who have had a really turbulent season with a lot of changes in coaches. The current coach is there for a second time this season; he has a special history here.”

“He’s a very experienced coach. It’s a team who have really found form again recently after ups and downs this season. They’ve played a lot of games but have now gone 10 games undefeated. It’s one of the toughest draws we could’ve got but it’s also one of the most exciting.”

“We’ll have the opportunity to play in this historic stadium. It has a really special energy that can be unleashed when the teams harness the energy from the fans. The noise that they make, it gives the team power and energy and we’ll have to be able to counter that.”

Celtic fans display a banner against the board during the Scottish Premiership match between Celtic and Falkirk at Celtic Park on February 01, 2026. (Photo by Ian MacNicol/Getty Images)

“But we’re prepared for the task ahead. It’s going to be really challenging, but these are the games you want to be competing in when you’re competing in Europe. We’re going to try and put ourselves in a good position heading into next week.”

Hoeness has highlighted several key players he believes pose a major danger in the Celtic ranks, while also warning that the club’s recent January arrivals could add further unpredictability and create significant challenges for his side.

The Stuttgart manager said: ”Yes, I would say so.. in general, you can say it’s a really experienced team.”

“Almost every player is around 26/27. They have two new players – Adamu and Cvancara – who are known from the Bundesliga, and the other played in the Premier League [Julian Araujo].”

Reo Hatate of Celtic celebrates scoring his team’s second goal with teammate Daizen Maeda during the UEFA Europa League 2025/26 League Phase MD5 match between Feyenoord and Celtic FC at De Kuip on November 27, 2025 in Rotterdam, Netherlands. (Photo by Dean Mouhtaropoulos/Getty Images)

“There’s another one that’s a little bit longer here [Arne Engels], he’s injured and a very talented player. Maeda is known and is capable of scoring very good goals.”

Benjamin Nygren of Celtic celebrates after scoring Kilmarnock v Celtic, Scottish Premiership, BBSP Rugby Park, Kilmarnock. 15 February 2026. Photo Pete Summers IMAGO/ Shutterstock

“Nygren showed this year that he’s capable of scoring a lot of goals. It’s a really good team. I think they have 13 or 14 really good players and that’s why I think it’s a really big challenge.”

Celtic in the Thirties by Matt Corr. Click on image to order

title: Celtic vs VfB Stuttgart – Predicted lineup and team news
description: Celtic and VfB Stuttgart face off at Celtic Park on Thursday evening in the first leg of the UEFA Europa League knockout round play-off, with a spot in the round of 16 at stake.The Bhoys ended the Eur...
fullText:
Celtic and VfB Stuttgart face off at Celtic Park on Thursday evening in the first leg of the UEFA Europa League knockout round play-off, with a spot in the round of 16 at stake.

The Bhoys ended the Europa League league phase in 21st place, collecting 11 points from eight matches and scoring 13 goals in the process.

Martin O’Neill’s side are currently enjoying a 10-game unbeaten run in all competitions and have found the net at least twice in each of their last five fixtures, a sequence that includes a 3–2 comeback win over Kilmarnock at the weekend.

Celtic have several injury problems to contend with ahead of Stuttgart’s visit.

Left-back Adam Montgomery is unavailable due to a calf issue, while right-back Alistair Johnston and midfielder Callum Osmand remain sidelined with hamstring and tendon problems and are not expected back until early March.

In central defence, Cameron Carter-Vickers is out for the rest of the season with an Achilles injury, and winger Jota is also ruled out long term after suffering a cruciate ligament problem, further reducing O’Neill’s choices both at the back and in wide attacking areas.

Belgian midfielder Arne Engels is another absentee; he is recovering from a thigh injury and is only anticipated to return to action in a week or two.

Possible Celtic starting XI: Schmeichel; Araujo, Trusty, Scales, Tierney; Nygren, McGregor, Hatate; Adamu, Cvancara, Maeda

The match will kick off at 8pm BST on Thursday, 19th February.

UK fans can watch the match live on TNT Sports 1 and TNT Sports Ultimate.

title: Max Clark Shows Elite Composure in Bizarre Spring Training Moment
description: A Detroit Tigers beat writer shares a hilarious and revealing spring training story about top prospect Max Clark calmly dealing with a broken tooth.
fullText:
If you’re looking for a snapshot of why the Detroit Tigers think so highly of Max Clark, it turns out you don’t need a highlight-reel catch or a towering home run.

During Tigers’ spring training in Lakeland, one Jeff Seidel of the Detroit Free Press stumbled into a moment that perfectly summed up Clark’s unflappable nature. After practice, Clark was standing in the clubhouse, calm as ever, when he was asked a routine question.

Before answering, Clark paused, walked over to a trash can — and casually emptied his mouth.

That’s when he delivered the line.

“I think I just broke a tooth.”

No panic. No urgency. No sprinting for medical help. Just a matter-of-fact observation, like he was commenting on the weather.

For a second, it didn’t quite register. Did he really just say that? Was that… his tooth? In the trash?

Clark poked around the back of his mouth, confirmed something was off, then shrugged it off like it was a minor inconvenience.

“We’ll get that figured out in a second,” he said.

And with that, he nodded — politely — and invited the interview to continue.

This wasn’t bravado. It wasn’t a tough-guy act. It was something much rarer: complete composure in a moment where most people would absolutely lose it.

A broken tooth would derail a lot of folks. At the very least, it would dominate the moment. Not with Clark.

Instead of rushing to a dentist or calling for help, he centered himself, made sure everything was under control, and shifted his focus back to the task at hand.

That’s the kind of detail scouts and coaches obsess over — not because of the tooth itself, but because of what it reveals under pressure.

Inside the Tigers organization, moments like this don’t shock anyone.

Clark has built a reputation as a prospect who doesn’t flinch. Big crowds, big expectations, uncomfortable moments — they don’t seem to rattle him. Whether it’s on the field or in a clubhouse conversation with a literal dental issue unfolding, his approach stays the same.

Stay calm. Stay focused. Handle the moment.

It’s easy to talk about tools, projections, and ceilings. But baseball people will tell you that makeup matters — and sometimes, it shows up in the strangest ways.

Like calmly finishing an interview… right after breaking a tooth.

The post Max Clark Shows Elite Composure in Bizarre Spring Training Moment appeared first on Detroit Sports Nation.

title: ‘Certain refs screw us over’ - Laporta hits out after Barca defeats
description: Match officials are in the spotlight right now.
fullText:
Joan Laporta is campaigning hard to win next month’s Barcelona elections and has taken aim at match officials in his latest speech.

The Barca chief was speaking after seeing Hansi Flick’s team left fuming by an eight-minute VAR delay against Atletico Madrid and angry at the decision to allow a late winner for Girona despite a foul on Jules Kounde.

Laporta claims some match officials have a real problem with Barcelona and has called on the team to play even better in the face of adversity.

“There are certain referees who, when they officiate our games, screw us over. Excuse my language, but it’s true. It’s a recurring issue, a constant problem. It’s a reality. I could name them all,” he told reporters.

“This hasn’t happened just once, but many times. In identical plays, they’ve been able to call the wrong thing to harm Barça. It’s blatant.

“We are defending Barça against everything and everyone. Against people who simply can’t accept who we are and what we represent. They can’t stand what we are achieving with our team. This is the only way they can stop us because they can’t stop us on the field.

“We have a team that can aspire to almost anything and face every possible adversity. The best way to deal with this dysfunction and its intentions is to be better and play better , to have a better team and overcome this adversity.”

Laporta also took aim at Real Madrid and feels Los Blancos receive preferential treatment.

“When we’re down, they try to take advantage and crush us. And when others are down, they help them,” he added.

“They’ve learned to swim and they dive in like a pro. We know we have to fight against all that too.”

Barcelona and Real Madrid are back in La Liga action this weekend. Real Madrid are up first on Saturday at Osasuna, while Barcelona play on Sunday against Levante.

title: Jaxson Hayes completes paperwork, eligible to play with Luka Doncic and Slovenia
description: Doncic and Hayes can now compete together in international play.
fullText:
Jaxson Hayes completes paperwork, eligible to play with Luka Doncic and Slovenia originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Ever since Luka Doncic joined the Los Angeles Lakers following last year's trade from the Dallas Mavericks, he's become fast friends with Los Angeles' backup center Jaxson Hayes.

So much so, that the duo discussed playing together for the Slovenian national team.

According to NBA insider Brian Windhorst, Hayes is now officially eligible to compete for Slovenia.

“Jaxson Hayes completed the paperwork to become a Slovenian,” Windhorst said. “He can join the Slovenian national team for Luka, which I’d like to say is one of the smartest things Jaxson Hayes has ever done because I think he’s just secretly signed a contract extension.”

As Windhorst points out, given the friendship between him and Hayes, there's a high probability that the Lakers keep him beyond this season due to that relationship.

Not to mention, for the money he's earning ($3.4 million) Hayes hasn't been a bad addition.

In 45 games for Los Angeles this season, he's averaging 6.9 points, 3.9 rebounds and one assist. Hayes is also benefitting from the strong passing ability of both Doncic and LeBron James, averaging a career-high 77.2% from the field, as the duo has helped him find easy looks inside the paint.

As long as Hayes can continue to play the pick-and-roll well with Los Angeles' ball-handlers, he'll have the opportunity to be effective in the Lakers' offense.

That said, at 7' 0", Hayes could be a bit better defensively, having never averaged one block or 

Either way, it appears Hayes could be a Laker for many seasons to come.

Doncic and Hayes will return to action following the All-Star break Feb. 20 against the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Blue Jays' Trey Yesavage leapfrogged shortstop in Toronto hierarchy
description: The young righty is on the rise.
fullText:
Blue Jays' Trey Yesavage leapfrogged shortstop in Toronto hierarchy originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Trey Yesavage's rise has been incredible.

That was exemplified at the end of last season, when he only showed up to the Toronto Blue Jays for the stretch run and then became a dominant postseason force anyway.

That was lifted expectations for the young right-hander sky high, and he'll have to do his best to meet them.

It also provided a cool chance for MLB.com's prospect ranking staff to look back. They wrote an article released Thursday which compared who they thought would be each organization's top-ranked prospect, which they predicted two years in advance, to who it actually is.

Yesavage pulled off a leapfrog for the Blue Jays.

The writers had predicted Arjun Nimmala, a shortstop who currently ranks 77th in their top-100. Yesavage ranks No. 12.

"Toronto’s three most recent first-round picks all feature in our Top 100, and while Nimmala (the 2023 20th overall pick) ranks third of the trio, that isn’t a knock against him," MLB.com's writers explain. "Still only 20 years old, the shortstop made nice improvements in terms of his chase rate at High-A Vancouver last year, and he has the potential to hit 25-plus homers at full maturity as he continues to add strength to his 6-foot-1 frame. He and top 2025 selection JoJo Parker could duke it out for the future of the shortstop position north of the border."

Given that Yesavage pitched across five levels of the organizational ladder in 2025, it's not shocking that he has risen from lower down the board to reach this point.

Clearly, he has even more believers now. His fastball-splitter combination has the potential to be dominant for years to come.

And it's not like Nimmala has fallen off too far. He can still become an MLB contributor, too.

title: ACC Roundup – Wake Surprises, Georgia Tech Withers
description: Wake Forest is getting healthy, Clemson, appears to be sick…but Georgia Tech may be terminal.
fullText:
In Wednesday’s ACC Action, Virginia clocked Georgia Tech, 94-68, and Wake Forest surprised Clemson, 85-77.

Wake Forest basically dominated the entire game. A week or two ago, who would have expected that?

Well, here’s something you may have missed – Clemson has lost three straight, to Virginia Tech, Duke and now Wake Forest. And all three losses were by double figures. Prior to this, the Tigers were 13-1 in their last 14 games. Brad Brownell has work to do.

Meanwhile, Wake Forest, despite not really having anyone inside to speak of, is catching fire late. Too late, probably, but it’s still impressive that the Deacs have won three straight.

Steve Forbes has continued to tinker with his lineup. In this one, he went with Tre’Von Spillers, Cooper Schwieger and Sebastian Akins up front and Juke Harris and Myles Colvin the backcourt. Harris led the way with 20 points.

Jake Wahlin paced the Tigers with 17.

As for Virginia, remember that scene in Braveheart when Longshanks realizes that if Wallace can take York, he can get the rest of England?

Virginia shot up 39-9 in the first half. Obviously, the game was over at that point. Georgia Tech gave up 59 points in the first half, en route to losing their eighth straight game.

The question isn’t really how bad it was. The question is the fallout. NC State got nuked at Louisville two games ago but bounced back nicely against UNC and is still on target for a tournament bid. Meanwhile, Georgia Tech is on target to miss the ACC Tournament, since the bottom three teams won’t go anymore.

However, it could still escape this fate as BC and Pitt also have just two ACC wins. We’ll see.

The other question is this: was it because the Yellow Jackets are really bad or because Virginia is really good?

Virginia has certainly been winning and has won eight straight road games, which is tremendous. However, the Wahoos beat SMU by 4, lost to UNC by 5, nipped Notre Dame by 3, BC by 13, FSU by 3 and Ohio State by 4. We’re tentatively going with the Yellow Jackets being that bad.

Over at WRAL, Pat Welter and Chris Lea discuss Hubert Davis’s UNC and reach the same conclusion we’ve discussed from time to time: Davis has no idea how to communicate with his team.

That doesn’t mean they won’t win games of course, but it does go a long way to explaining why guys who transfer from UNC do so well at their new schools. Consider Michigan’s Elliott Cadeau, Minnesota’s Cade Tyson and Vanderbilt’s Tyler Nickel for a few quick examples. Consider also that Caleb Love became a consistent and reliable presence at Arizona in his final two years.
